fr.sii.ogham.email.builder.sendgrid

Class SendGridBuilder

  • java.lang.Object
    • fr.sii.ogham.core.builder.AbstractParent<EmailBuilder>
      • fr.sii.ogham.email.builder.sendgrid.SendGridBuilder
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Builder<SendGridSender>, Parent<EmailBuilder>

    public class SendGridBuilder
extends AbstractParent<EmailBuilder>
implements Builder<SendGridSender>
    Configures how SendGrid implementation will send Emails. This implementation uses SendGrid HTTP API.

    To send Email using SendGrid, you need to register this builder into a MessagingBuilder like this: 

     
 MessagingBuilder msgBuilder = ...
 msgBuilder.email()
    .sender(SendGridBuilder.class)    // registers the builder and accesses to that builder for configuring it
    Once the builder is registered, sending email through SendGrid requires either an API key or a username/password pair. You can define it using: 
     
 msgBuilder.email()
    .sender(SendGridBuilder.class)    // registers the builder and accesses to that builder for configuring it
       .apiKey("foo")
    Or you can also use property keys (using interpolation): 
     
 msgBuilder
 .environment()
    .properties()
       .set("custom.property.for.api-key", "foo")
       .and()
    .and()
 .email()
    .sender(SendGridBuilder.class)    // registers the builder and accesses to that builder for configuring it
       .host("${custom.property.for.api-key}")

    Finally, Ogham will transform general Email object into SendGrid.Email object. This transformation will fit almost all use cases but you may need to customize a part of the SendGrid message. Instead of doing again the same work Ogham does, this builder allows you to intercept the message to modify it just before sending it: 

     
 .sender(SendGridBuilder.class)
    .intercept(new MyCustomInterceptor())
    See SendGridInterceptor for more information.
    Author:
    Aur√©lien Baudet

    • Method Detail

      • apiKey

        public SendGridBuilder apiKey(String... key)
        Set SendGrid API key. You can specify a direct value. For example: 
         .apiKey("localhost");

        You can also specify one or several property keys. For example: 

         .apiKey("${custom.property.high-priority}", "${custom.property.low-priority}");
        The properties are not immediately evaluated. The evaluation will be done when the build() method is called. If you provide several property keys, evaluation will be done on the first key and if the property exists (see EnvironmentBuilder), its value is used. If the first property doesn't exist in properties, then it tries with the second one and so on.
        Parameters:
        key - one value, or one or several property keys
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • username

        public SendGridBuilder username(String... username)
        Set username for SendGrid HTTP API. You can specify a direct value. For example: 
         .username("foo");

        You can also specify one or several property keys. For example: 

         .username("${custom.property.high-priority}", "${custom.property.low-priority}");
        The properties are not immediately evaluated. The evaluation will be done when the build() method is called. If you provide several property keys, evaluation will be done on the first key and if the property exists (see EnvironmentBuilder), its value is used. If the first property doesn't exist in properties, then it tries with the second one and so on.
        Parameters:
        username - one value, or one or several property keys
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • password

        public SendGridBuilder password(String... password)
        Set password for SendGrid HTTP API. You can specify a direct value. For example: 
         .password("foo");

        You can also specify one or several property keys. For example: 

         .password("${custom.property.high-priority}", "${custom.property.low-priority}");
        The properties are not immediately evaluated. The evaluation will be done when the build() method is called. If you provide several property keys, evaluation will be done on the first key and if the property exists (see EnvironmentBuilder), its value is used. If the first property doesn't exist in properties, then it tries with the second one and so on.
        Parameters:
        password - one value, or one or several property keys
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • client

        public SendGridBuilder client(SendGridClient client)
        By default, calling SendGrid HTTP API is done through the default SendGrid implementation. If you want to use another client implementation (creating your custom HTTP API caller for example), you can implement the SendGridClient interface and provide it: 
         .client(new MyCustomHttpApiCaller())
        NOTE: if you provide your custom implementation, any defined properties and values using apiKey(String...), username(String...) or password(String...) won't be used at all. You then have to handle it by yourself.
        Parameters:
        client - the custom client used to call SendGrid HTTP API
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • mimetype

        public MimetypeDetectionBuilder<SendGridBuilder> mimetype()
        Builder that configures mimetype detection. There exists several implementations to provide the mimetype:
        • Using Java MimetypesFileTypeMap
        • Using Java 7 Files.probeContentType(java.nio.file.Path)
        • Using Apache Tika
        • Using JMimeMagic

        Both implementations provided by Java are based on file extensions. This can't be used in most cases as we often handle InputStreams.

        In previous version of Ogham, JMimeMagic was used and was working quite well. Unfortunately, the library is no more maintained.

        You can configure how Tika will detect mimetype: 

         .mimetype()
    .tika()
       ...

        This builder allows to use several providers. It will chain them until one can find a valid mimetype. If none is found, you can explicitly provide the default one: 

         .mimetype()
    .defaultMimetype("text/html")

        If no mimetype detector was previously defined, it creates a new one. Then each time you call mimetype(), the same instance is used.

        Returns:
        the builder to configure mimetype detection

      • mimetype

        public SendGridBuilder mimetype(MimetypeDetectionBuilder<?> builder)
        NOTE: this is mostly for advance usage (when creating a custom module). Inherits mimetype configuration from another builder. This is useful for configuring independently different parts of Ogham but keeping a whole coherence (see DefaultSendGridConfigurer for an example of use). The same instance is shared meaning that all changes done here will also impact the other builder.

        If a previous builder was defined (by calling mimetype() for example), the new builder will override it.

        Parameters:
        builder - the builder to inherit
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • environment

        public EnvironmentBuilder<SendGridBuilder> environment()
        Configures environment for the builder (and sub-builders). Environment consists of configuration properties/values that are used to configure the system (see EnvironmentBuilder for more information). You can use system properties: 
         .environment()
    .systemProperties();
        Or, you can load properties from a file: 
         .environment()
    .properties("/path/to/file.properties")
        Or using directly a Properties object: 
         Properties myprops = new Properties();
 myprops.setProperty("foo", "bar");
 .environment()
    .properties(myprops)
        Or defining directly properties: 
         .environment()
    .properties()
       .set("foo", "bar")

        If no environment was previously used, it creates a new one. Then each time you call environment(), the same instance is used.

        Returns:
        the builder to configure properties handling

      • environment

        public SendGridBuilder environment(EnvironmentBuilder<?> builder)
        NOTE: this is mostly for advance usage (when creating a custom module). Inherits environment configuration from another builder. This is useful for configuring independently different parts of Ogham but keeping a whole coherence (see DefaultSendGridConfigurer for an example of use). The same instance is shared meaning that all changes done here will also impact the other builder.

        If a previous builder was defined (by calling environment() for example), the new builder will override it.

        Parameters:
        builder - the builder to inherit
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining

      • intercept

        public SendGridBuilder intercept(SendGridInterceptor interceptor)
        Ogham will transform general Email object into SendGrid.Email objects. This transformation will fit almost all use cases but you may need to customize a part of the SendGrid message. Instead of doing again the same work Ogham does, this builder allows you to intercept the message to modify it just before sending it: 
         .sender(SendGridBuilder.class)
    .intercept(new MyCustomInterceptor())
        See SendGridInterceptor for more information.
        Parameters:
        interceptor - the custom interceptor used to modify SendGrid.Email
        Returns:
        this instance for fluent chaining
